Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research Opportunities at the Interface of Computational and Experimental Chemistry at the University of North Texas
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site led by Angela K. Wilson and LeGrande Slaughter at the University of North Texas for three summers, starting in 2015. The Site is entitled, "Opportunities in Chemistry at the Interface of Computation and Experiment at the University of North Texas." The site will support eight students per summer in a ten week program. The UNT Chemistry Department is a Ph.D.-granting program with a strong record of undergraduate research involvement. Emphasis in the proposed REU site is placed on the integration of computational chemistry and experiment. Students will undergo diverse training at the interface of theory and experiment, in areas such as solar cells, catalysis, forensic chemistry, semiconductors, chemical sensors, targeted molecule delivery, atmospheric chemistry, interfacial chemistry, and theoretical chemistry.

The UNT REU program will focus on increasing research opportunities for a diverse group of students, with special efforts to recruit students from underserved populations and institutions, and students at the early stage of their undergraduate studies. Students will be exposed to a wide range of career, research, community service, and leadership opportunities in chemistry, including direct interactions with successful chemists, and visits to companies. Successful attainment of the program goals will enhance the infrastructure for science education for underserved populations, and continued contacts with REU participants and partnering predominantly undergraduate institutions (PUIs) will enable identification of effective practices for promoting research success, which will be disseminated to the broader research community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is no more effective way to inspire the nation's talented young people to contribute to scientific progress than through high-quality undergraduate research experiences.  The experience of applying fundamental knowledge of chemistry outside the classroom, on a real problem with real-world implications, is often a turning point in the career of a budding scientist.  It can open a world of opportunity and excitement that the student would not have been aware of otherwise.

This project developed a Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) Site in the Chemistry Department at the University of North Texas (UNT) aimed at integrating two important, but disparate, facets of modern research--experimental and computational chemistry--in the comprehensive research training of talented undergraduate students.  With the ubiquitous availability of powerful computers, chemists now have access to powerful computational research methods that were undreamed of a few years ago.  In this REU program, a total of 29 undergraduate students over the 2015-2018 period were trained in both computational and experimental methods, enhancing their ability to attack scientific challenges at the forefront of chemistry.  These student pursued research projects in areas ranging from prediction of cancer biomarkers, to design of selective catalysts, to corrosion prevention in electronic materials, to creation of new materials for solar cells and energy-efficient lighting.

Each summer over the grant period, a group of 5-8 REU Scholars spent 10 weeks at UNT working closely with one of 13 faculty mentors on a topical research project, typically also receiving training from a graduate student "lab mentor."  Students were prepared to achieve a significant degree of independence early in the summer through participation in two "Research Boot Camps" that provided accelerated training in experimental methods (nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy) and computational methods (density functional theory calculations) that are mainstays of modern chemical research.  In parallel to their research activities, students were trained in scientific communication skills, including required midsummer and final oral presentations and a final poster presentation. 

The program took a holistic approach to scientific training, combining lab work with a range of professional development activities designed to prepare the students for successful careers in science.  These activities included visits to local industrial facilities that do research in forensic chemistry, materials chemistry, and cosmetic chemistry; interactive seminars led by career-active chemists on how to prepare for scientific careers in industry; faculty-led sessions on graduate studies in chemistry, scientific meetings, and networking; and a yearly Women in Chemistry discussion that introduced students to challenges and opportunities facing women in the chemical sciences.  One of the most impactful activities was a yearly two-part seminar on Scientific Ethics, in which students researched and gave presentations on various types of misconduct and ethical issues in the chemical sciences.  These discussions provided the students with important perspectives on the responsibilities that come with being a professional scientist. 

A special focus of the UNT Chemistry REU program has been on students at non-Ph.D.-granting, primarily undergraduate colleges and universities, which often have limited or no resources for involving undergraduate students in research.  Of the 29 participants, 26 came from this type of institution.  The program also achieved a high level of participation from students in underrepresented groups, including eight Hispanic/Latinx students, five Black or African-American students, and 14 women.  In addition, 13 participants were early-stage students who had completed no more than two years of college and had no prior research experience. 

The program has seen significant success in preparing this diverse group of REU scholars for further success in their careers, as evidenced by a strong record of acceptance by our former scholars into graduate and professional programs.  To date, 14 former participants in our program have pursued doctoral studies in chemistry-related fields, many at highly ranked institutions including MIT, Northwestern, Cornell, and the University of Michigan.  Two former participants are attending medical school, and two are working in the chemical industry. 

The broader impacts to society of the UNT Chemistry REU program include nurturing a pool of young scientists to become better prepared to contribute to the modern scientific workforce; increasing the gender, racial and ethnic diversity of this pool; integrating awareness of scientific ethics into research training of undergraduates; and catalyzing the synergy of computational and experimental chemistry to enable new discoveries that can improve human life.
